metadata.title: Stereoselective reduction of steroids with <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> prepared phosphine rhodium catalysts

KOLLAR, S. TOROS, B. HEIL Institute of Organic Chemistry, University of Chemical Engineering, H-8201 Veszprem, P.O. Box 1S8 (Hungary) and Z. TUBA Chemical Works ofGedeon Richter Ltd., H-1103 Budapest, Gyomroi ut 19/21 (Hungary) (Received September 23, 1987; accepted December 21, 1987) Summary Stereoselective homogeneous hydrogenation of steroids with rhodium- phosphine catalysts prepared in situ has been investigated, and the activity and selectivity of these catalysts altered by variation of the phospine ligands. The influence of solvents, temperature and added bases was studied as well. Reducing 3-oxo-4-ene steroids gave mainly the ^rans-anellated Ba-derivatives. The most favourable isomer ratio (5a:5j3 = 9:1) was observed in the hy- drogenation of 4-androstene-3,17-dione. Introduction Hydrogenation of steroids with heterogeneous catalysts has been well investigated [1-8]. While reduction of A^steroids resulted mainly in mix- tures of Sa- and 5|3-steroids with the 5j3 isomers predominating [2-6], formation of the 50: derivative as major product was reported only in hydro- genation of testosterone [5-6]. Little information is available from the literature about the reduction of steroids with homogeneous catalysts [1, 9 - 14]. Although Rh(Ph3P)3Cl hydrogenates A4 steroids selectively from the a face, the reaction requires days and yields are rather low [9]. Higher activity and 5a-selectivity is reported only with a soluble iridium catalyst [12]. Our earlier results m the selective hydrogenation of cyclic ketones with catalysts prepared in situ from [Rh(NBD)Cl]2 and tertiary phosphines of different structure prompted *Presented partly at the 2nd International Conference of Chemistry and Biotech- nology of Biologically Active Natural Products, Budapest, Hungary, 15 - 19 August 1983, Proc. 97. 0304-5102/88/$3.50 Eisevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 34 us to investigate the reduction of steroids with these systems. In this paper homogeneous selective hydrogenation of A4- and A^steroids will be de- scribed and, for comparison, reduction of model compounds with a hetero- geneous Pd/C catalyst is also reported. Results and discussion Hydrogenation of 4-androstene-3,17-dione (1) with rhodium-phosphine catalysts prepared in situ occurs under the conditions specified in Table 1. Activity and selectivity of the catalysts strongly depend on the solvent and the ligand properties. The latter were varied over a wide range of Tolman's electronic parameters [15] and steric requirements [16]. Rh(Ph3P)3Cl and catalysts formed m situ from phosphines of lower basicity promote mainly the formation of 5o! derivatives, in contrast to the heterogeneous Pd/C catalyst. There is only one exception: Ph2(o-Tol)P, a bulky phosphine (0-roi = 161 ) of low basicity, doesn't coordinate to the metal and a hetero- geneous rhodium system is active, producing mainly the 5j3H steroid isomer. On changing the ligand from the less basic arylphosphines to the highly basic Bu3P, dissociation of the ligand from the coordinatively saturated H2Rh(Bu3P)3Cl complex is slow in benzene, and consequently low reaction rates are observed. Working in a more polar MeOH/CeHs solvent mixture, reduction of the keto groups competes with the olefin hydrogenation. 1 2 4 5 High reaction rate and most favourable isomer ratio (5oc:5ss = 9:1) were achieved with PhiMeP as ligand in an i-PrOH/CsHe solvent mixture. The reaction rate was acceptable even at a Rh/substrate = 1/200 ratio. Separation by column chromatography and recrystallization yielded 70% 5aH-3,17- dione. While addition of Et3N does not alter the product distribution, in / -.^a04-' S S'SUI' Q -8 - 0 'e ? s uewl0,^Ei0 ^l 'oCO+3^ a ua ri a>a0'v t~r-lro"1000''S t-i-iro'? 10^-t ^ ^J u 'o Oi ^l ^'"!^loo'^'^l<c<lmoo 0l00if-^tOC4C<ltOOC<lT-lt-~(DC<l I-( -<T-II-~ r-ltOtOtOC<ltOtOOOin'Mi-IOiOT-lc~coc~c~cocot-QO<Mroc~ OIOOQOIM u omc-i-iioootONtOt-oo'^oioo o-<r^fro>o<ooic<iTfwooooio^T-l r-1 r-1 000000000000000e<iiomioiom>o>om>nior~c~i t r-i r-t r-< l-( T-( ^ ^< ^1 ^4 ^< 11 11 11 H 11 ^ sO >0 'O 'U%%%%% cJu u u ui a aaffi A 'g itQ. t~i-l(0:roa10^ ro ^ +'o ''StQ.1-J3' '-1 ^ oco ro" a2 '" S , 3 l; + I | .B 9.2 a ^ ^ .^ih (u .- v B ' -S oa. a /-)^ a ro s '-' & ffi -" wo-s"2 gaM 5 ^ s 10 -Oro 8^ " E + 2 +'~1 E 2 o" 2 ^ g^S-^l^.e^SroSrojgaJSa^ .10 g in u;^^ "^ ' t0 Tf ^3 r-15 d + Qi +OE td .0 CJ '0 S%%%%%%%"% g lauuuuuuuuuS.S.S.I.Sma^ %8 >-, '? -" Bs% A ft. "2 ^ " .S- + +w &<[2 (lL|PL|ft<eL|+ Out"' OJOJOJO) ^^ g^3; ^^^c.^3^3 o.-a.a ^^-c-c-c-fihCLi OpLiCLi IDPQp^h&ifri -r+ +++ ++++++ ^uOR-i^^u^So.y.u,oo^QQ^QQQ^QQQQQQ^ ^ m-cMOQCQiofficQtnpQam --gzze^zzz.-zzzz^z S^.C-AJi'CJS^axiy.^s^^^A^a ggoirtglpiciiKgtfoaoiiaoipa 36 presence of the still more basic NaOCH3 the 5j3H isomer predominates. We assume that this is a consequence of HC1 abstraction from the rhodium- phosphine-chloro complex and that a monohydrido-rhodium-phosphine complex is active [17]. This assumption is also supported by the similar product distribution in the HRh(Ph3P)4-catalyzed reaction. Similar product distribution was found in hydrogenation of 17a- methyltestosterone (2). Reduction with the palladium catalyst resulted predominantly in the 5j3H-3-one derivative, but with homogeneous catalysts mainly the SaH-isomer was formed (Table 2). The polar alcohol group of the substrate (17-OH) deactivates the homogeneous catalysts. In accordance with our earlier findings [17], in the presence of Et3N abstraction of HC1 takes place from the Pl^P-containing Wilkinson complex, and competitive stereoselective reduction of the keto group catalyzed by the monohydrido- rhodium species occurs. Essentially the same steroid isomers were formed in hydrogenation of 4-cholestene-3-one (3) with different catalysts (Table 3). To investigate the reduction of A^steroids, hydrogenation of 5- cholestene-3ss-ol (4), 5,16-pregnadiene-3|3-ol-20-one acetate (5), 5-pregnene- 3(3-ol-20-one acetate and 5-androstene-3,17-dione-diethylene ketal was carried out. The double bond in cholesterol (4) is sterically hindered, and its hydrogenation takes place, but sluggishly even under drastic conditions: the 5aH-isomer is formed exclusively. Rh(Ph3P)3Cl is inert even under high pressure (Table 4). On hydrogenat- ing 5,16-pregnadiene-3ss-ol-20-one acetate, the double bond of the five- membered ring is easily saturated but reduction of A5 does not occur, even under conditions where the keto group is already hydrogenated (Table 5). 5-Pregnene-3(3-ol-20-one acetate A5 is slightly reactive but the unsaturated alcohol is the major product; the 5ssH-steroid isomer was never detected. We were entirely unsuccessful in hydrogenation of 5-androstene-3,17-dione- diethylene ketal. Experimental Materials Solvents were dried and distilled under argon. The catalytic precursors, phosphines and steroids were purchased from Strem Chemicals Inc., Fluka and Aldrich. Hydrogenation experiments (general procedure) The catalytic system was prepared in situ under argon from 0.025 mmol [Rh(NBD)Cl]2 and 0.15 mmol phosphine in 5 ml solvent. After prehydrogenation (20 min at 50 C) the steroid was added from a bulb to the catalytic solution. Hydrogenations were performed in a glass reactor at atmospheric pressure under the reaction conditions given in Tables 1-5. The ratio of 5o:- and 5j3-androsta-3,17-dione epimers was found unchanged after chromatography. 5o:-androsta-3,17-dione was isolated by recrystallization from ether as a pure white powder (checked by GLC) in 70% yield. coredata.dc:description: Stereoselective homogeneous hydrogenation of steroids with rhodium-phosphine catalysts prepared in situ has been investigated, and the activity and selectivity of these catalysts altered by variation of the phospine ligands. The influence of solvents, temperature and added bases was studied as well. Reducing 3-oxo-4-ene steroids gave mainly the trans-anellated 5α-derivatives. The most favourable isomer ratio (5α:5β = 9:1) was observed in the hydrogenation of 4-androstene-3,17-dione.
coredata.dc:title: Stereoselective reduction of steroids with in situ prepared phosphine rhodium catalysts
